exercise.title: Black Vine Cyber Espionage Group
exercise.name: black_vine
exercise.shortdescription: Read and analyze the Black Vine Cyber Espionage Group Report.
exercise.description: Read the Black Vine Report to understand one set of TTPs(tactics, techniques, procedures), belonging to a nation states cyber actors.
exercise.tutorial:
1. On your defensive workstation, open the ShareFiles drive, and Vendor Reports Directory.
  2. Select the Black Vine Cyber Espionage Group
  3. Read and analyze the report to answer the questions below.

question.text: Black Vine uses the Elderwood Framework, which distributes zero-day exploits to its targets. What is the Elderwood framework?
question.answer: A combination of spear phishing emails, and watering holes that require the delivery of a trojan to infect the targeted computer.
question.wrong: Watering holes used to lure targets in and exploit them via iframes.

question.text: What is Black Vines custom-developed malware?
What location does the trojan Sakurel copy itself too?
What server does Sakurel connect to and then open a remote shell?
How does Sakurel stay persistent on an infected target past reboot?
When backdoor.mivast is executed, what is one of the files it creates?
What is one of the locations Mivast may connect back to?
Does Sakurel and Mivast work on Windows 10?
Who(m) signs the digital certificates for the malware used by Black Vine?
question.answer: DTOPTOOLZ Co or MICRO DIGITAL INC

question.text: What is one of the c&c domains used?
How did Symantec associate Topsec Network Security with the Anthem breach?
question.answer: The domain topsec2014.com was registered to 192.199.254.126 around the same time that Miravast called back to C&C infrastructure hosted on the same IP address.
question.wrong: A reverse dns lookup of 192.199.254.126 resolved to just one domain: topsec.com.

question.text: What industries were/are affected by Black Vine?
When was Black Vine first seen?
What city is Black Vine attributed to?
